name: Saola
notes: No individuals in captivity. Wild population highly dispersed, and subpopulations fragmented with numbers of mature individuals below the minimum viable population. Foremost threatened by hunting.

name: Bawean deer
notes: Estimates are for the wild population only; may reach as high as 500.

name: Pygmy hippopotamus
notes: Estimate is from 1993; numbers have probably shrunk.

name: Rhim gazelle
notes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.

name: Mountain Nyala
notes: 2500 is a maximum estimate from 1999, but recent work has shown numbers may be as high as 4000.

name: European bison
notes: Includes 1400 semi-domestic animals and 1800 wild. Semi-domestic numbers are likely underestimated.

name: Chacoan peccary
notes: Estimate was made in 2002; wide-scale deforestation of their habitat began in 2003.

name: Jentink's duiker
notes: Maximum estimate; may be less than 2000.

name: Arabian Oryx
notes: 6000 – 7000 in captivity and ~1000 in the wild.

name: Banteng
notes: Maximum estimate; may be fewer than 5000. Numbers do not include the non-purebred domestic variety.

name: Zebra duiker
notes: Could be overestimated; may be less than 15 000.

name: Alpine ibex
notes: Was as low as 100 individuals in the 1800s.

name: Mountain reedbuck
notes: Minimum estimate, divided into three subspecies: Southern (33 000), Chanler's (2900), and Western (450).

name: Blackbuck
notes: Numbers have increased from 20 – 24 000 in the 1970s.

name: Saiga Antelope
notes: Numbers stood at 1 250 000 in the mid-1970s.

name: East African oryx
notes: Divided into two subspecies: Beisa (50 000) and Fringe-eared (17 000).

name: Sharpe's Grysbok
notes: Difficult to study due to the animal's nocturnal nature; numbers may be underestimated.

name: Sitatunga
notes: Yet-to-be-published research suggests the population has been overestimated.

name: Waterbuck
notes: About 95 000 of the Defassa subspecies and 105 000 of the Common.

name: Lechwe
notes: Combined numbers of three subspecies: Red (98 000), Kafue (78 000), and Black (36 000).

name: American bison
notes: Includes 500 000 semi-domestic animals and 30 000 wild (19 000 plains bison and 11 000 wood bison).

name: Pronghorn
notes: Numbered over 35 million in the early 1800s and as little as 20 000 in the early 1920s.

name: African buffalo
notes: Considered conservative. Divided into four subspecies: West African Savanna (27 000), Central African Savanna (133 000), Southern Savanna (670 000), & Forest (60 000).

name: Siberian roe deer
notes: About 500 000 were hunted annually in Russia in the 1800s.

name: Common duiker
notes: Considered extremely conservative; yet-to-be-published research shows it may number as high as 10 000 000.

name: Water buffalo
population:
172 000 000
incl. 3.2 Million Carabao in the Philippines

name: Hainan black crested gibbon
notes: Population was estimated at over 2000 in the late 1950s.

name: Blond capuchin
notes: Estimate is for mature individuals only.

name: Perrier's sifaka
notes: One of the 25 most endangered primates.

name: Silky sifaka
notes: Estimate is believed to be a maximum.

name: Golden lion tamarin
notes: Minimum estimate; wild only. In addition to these, there are about 450 golden lion tamarins in 150 zoos around the world.

name: Black snub-nosed monkey
notes: Maximum estimate; less than 1000 mature organisms.

name: Lac Alaotra bamboo lemur
notes: Estimates were for 2002 and showed a decline of over 50% in under a ten years.

name: Gee's golden langur
notes: Maximum estimate; mature individuals number less than 2500.

name: Eastern gorilla
notes: Approximately 5000 eastern lowland gorillas (G. b. graueri) and 880 mountain gorillas (G. b. beringei).

name: Nilgiri langur
notes: Maximum estimate; mature individuals number less than 10 000.

name: Giant golden-crowned flying fox
notes: Rough estimate; probably no more than 20 000.

name: Grey-headed flying fox
notes: Estimates are based on incomplete knowledge of camp location and use.

name: Indiana bat
notes: Though numbers are large compared to other bats classified as endangered, this species is listed as such due to a >50% decline over the past decade.

name: Przewalski's horse
notes: Wild numbers only. Previously extinct in the wild.

name: African wild ass
notes: Maximum estimate. A small population may still exist in Somalia.

name: Black rhinoceros
notes: Four subspecies: Southern-central (2220), South-western (1920), Eastern (740), and Western (0; considered recently extinct).

name: Iberian lynx
notes: According to European Union LIFE Nature conservation projects estimates population size tripled from 52 mature individuals in 2002 to 156 in 2012.

name: Iriomote cat
notes: A subspecies of the leopard cat living exclusively on the Japanese island of Iriomote. Population size is declining, and consists of a single subpopulation.

name: Red wolf
notes: Maximum estimate. No more than 50 mature individuals. Previously extinct in the wild.

name: Cozumel raccoon
notes: Mature individuals number less than 250. Populations can be severely affected by hurricanes.

name: Ethiopian wolf
notes: One of the world's rarest canids, and Africa's most endangered carnivore.

name: Hawaiian monk seal
notes: Numbered 1448 in 1983. Rate of decrease appears to be rising.

name: Marine otter
notes: Maximum estimate from 1991; numbers have probably fallen.

name: Black-footed ferret
notes: Maximum estimate. 1,000 wild and 300 domestic. Almost became extinct in the 1980s.

name: Island fox
notes: Maximum estimate in 2002. Numbers had declined from 6,000 in 1994 and appear to be continuing the trend, so present numbers are likely much lower.

name: Cheetah
notes: Estimate is for mature individuals only. Number may reach as high as 10,000.

name: Juan Fernández fur seal
notes: Estimate is from the early 1990s; numbers appear to be increasing.

name: Lion
notes: Comprises several subspecies in Africa and Asia. The former has higher population and most subspecies: a recent study has given a global range of 29,000 – 47,000. The Asiatic species numbers an estimated 650.

name: Steller sea lion
notes: Divided into two subspecies: Western Steller (78,000) and Loughlin’s Steller (65,000).

name: Brown bear
notes: Minimum estimate. Russia has the largest number of brown bears, believed to exceed 100, 000, while estimates in the U.S. are around 33, 000 (most in Alaska), Canada 25, 000, and Europe (excluding Russia) 14, 000.

name: Subantarctic fur seal
notes: Estimate is from 1987; almost certainly an underestimate.

name: Southern elephant seal
notes: Latest global estimates are from the mid-1990s.

name: Hooded seal
notes: 592,000 in the Northwest Atlantic and 70,000 in the Northeast. The latter population has declined 85-90% in the past 60 years for unknown reasons.

name: American black bear
notes: Numbers are believed to be twice that of all other bears combined.

name: Brown fur seal
notes: Divided into two subspecies: Cape (2,000,000) and Australian (92,000).

name: Crabeater seal
notes: Estimates are highly uncertain due to their widespread distribution on the pack ice surrounding Antarctica.

name: Red fox
notes: Estimates are uncertain because a coordinated worldwide census has never been conducted.
